title: R43887
content: The Older Americans Act (OAA), enacted in 1965, provides social services and programs for individuals aged 60 and older. Services include nutrition programs, caregiver support, employment services, and programs to prevent abuse. Most programs are administered by the Administration on Aging (AOA) within the Department of Health and Human Services, except for Title V which is administered by the Department of Labor. The Older Americans Act (OAA) provides social services for individuals aged 60 and older. Title V is administered by the Department of Labor. Congress has reauthorized and amended the act multiple times, with the last reauthorization in 2006. Funding for OAA Titles II, III, IV, VI, and VII comes from HHS appropriations, while Title V funding comes from DOL appropriations. The Older Americans Act Amendments of 2006 (P.L. 109-365) authorized appropriations through FY2011. Despite the expiration of authorizations, Congress has continued to fund OAA programs. This report discusses OAA funding, including FY2015 funding breakdown, legislative activity, and funding decisions for selected programs. Appendix A details authorizations of appropriations under the 2006 Amendments. The FY2015 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act (P.L. 113-235) funded OAA programs at $1.878 billion, a slight increase from FY2014. Appendix A provides authorizations of appropriations under the 2006 Older Americans Act Amendments. Appendix B shows funding levels for OAA programs from FY2006 through FY2015. For more information on the Older Americans Act, refer to CRS Report R43414. The FY2015 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act (P.L. 113-235) funded OAA programs at $1.878 billion, slightly more than FY2014. Title III programs received the largest proportion of funding at 70.7%, with allocations to nutrition, supportive services, family caregivers, and health promotion activities. Title V, the CSEOA Program, received 23.1% of funding, while the remaining funds were allocated to other OAA programs. In FY2015, OAA programs received $1.878 billion in funding, slightly more than FY2014. Elder rights protection activities under Title VII received 1.1% of the funding. Aging Network Support Activities and Elder Rights Support Activities under Title IV received new funding in FY2015 for Holocaust survivors and an Elder Justice Initiative. Total discretionary funding for OAA programs increased slightly from FY2001 to FY2002, remained flat through FY2006, and increased annually from FY2006 to FY2010. Total discretionary funding for OAA programs declined from FY2011 to FY2013, with FY2013 funding falling below the FY2007 level. The reduction in funding from FY2012 to FY2013 is mainly due to sequestration. Funding for FY2014 and FY2015 was slightly above FY2013 but below FY2012 levels. Aging and Disability Resource Centers (ADRCs) aim to provide a single entry point for information on long-term services and supports, offering counseling, access to public programs, discharge planning, and care transition services. There are over 500 ADRC sites nationwide, with 5.2 million client contacts in FY2012. In FY2012, ADRCs had 5.2 million contacts with clients and received $10 million in mandatory funding under the ACA. The President's FY2015 budget proposed no discretionary funding for ADRCs but included $20.0 million each year for five years in renewed mandatory funding. Additional funding could help ADRC programs assist states in meeting needs. The budget justification highlighted the $100 million provided since 2003 for ADRC services and the potential for additional funding to support states in meeting Medicaid requirements. The Senate bill proposed $6.1 million in discretionary funding for ADRCs and urged improved coordination among ADRCs, AAAs, and CILs. H.R. 5464 did not specify a dollar amount for ADRCs, but FY2015-enacted funding allocated $6.1 million in discretionary funding, the same as FY2014. The President's budget request for additional mandatory funding was not fulfilled. The White House Conferences on Aging have historically focused on concerns of older individuals and provided guidance to federal policymakers. The President's FY2015 budget requested $3.0 million for a White House Conference on Aging, but did not specify a dollar amount for ADRCs, which received $6.1 million in discretionary funding. The budget justification noted previous funding for ADRC services and the Senate bill proposed improved coordination among ADRCs, AAAs, and CILs. The White House Conference on Aging has been held in various decades, with the most recent one planned for 2015. While the President's budget proposed funding for the conference, the Senate bill did not allocate dedicated funding. The conference is expected to take place in Washington, DC, with a scaled-down scope due to lack of direct appropriations. The White House Conference on Aging in 2015 will be held in Washington, DC with a scaled-down scope due to lack of direct appropriations. It will recognize the anniversaries of Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and the Older Americans Act, focusing on retirement security, healthy aging, long-term services and supports, and elder justice.
